s2: ^ Travel not to the Netherworld alone for demons lie in wait.

b: ^Khepri, King of scarabs, Lord of the rising sun, heed my warning.
^Darkness will decend upon all of Lunu. The sea will glitter for the final time!
^A child has thrust themselves in my path, warning of the decent of endless darkness upon Lunu, my beloved land.

Child: ^I raise this sun every morning my child. Why should this night be different?
^Silence! Who are you to warn a God?
Child2: ^You carry the sun through the Netherworld so that we might have night, but I have heard tell of a traitor in your path!
^Someone you trust with all your light has joined the army of Apophis and plots against you.
^There are whispers of betrayal. Could my ally really collude with the beasts of the Netherworld? Who could this 'friend' be?
^Pray tell, Who is this traitor? How did you hear of them?
^Am I to believe the concoctions of child? Be off with you.

c-0: ^The Spririt in the Sphynx whispers of your fate. Find it and you will have your answer.
^There are whispers of betrayal. Could my ally really collude with the beasts of the Netherworld? Who could this 'friend' be? I must find the sphynx to discover their identity

Trust: ^You will not hear my warning? Beware of those whom you most trust, sire!
Skull: ^I have tripped upon a sparking skull. Perhaps there is more it than a mere obstacle?
^I have heard murmurs of a 'loyal' scarab who might soon plunge a dagger into my shell. Tell me all you know.

c-2.#: A skull sparkles faintly in the sand

SPEAK: ^I weigh nothing, but you cannot hold me for long. What am I?

c-0: ^Incorrect my king, you cannot hold light for any time.
c-1: ^Well guessed, Khepri. Now leave me in peace.
c-2: ^Incorrect my king, you cannot hold wind for any time.

Skull2: ^Let us bargain, Khepri, Lord of the rising sun.
^I shall tell you a tale of betrayal, if you can answer me this.
^I live not, yet I grow. I breathe not, yet I need air. Drown me and I shall die. What am I?

c-0: ^A fool's answer. Begone before I swallow you whole.
c-1: ^What? No. Are you the God of ignorance?
c-2: ^Lord Khepri, you are wiser than you appear. You shall have the answer you seek.
^A scarab will indeed betray you, and serve your head to their Lord Apophis. You may find the traitor lurking amid the western pyramids.
^A scarab who lies in the western pyramids is plotting to serve my head to his new Lord Apophis.

b: ^Help me! King of Scarabs, have you heard my prayers?
^Will you help me find my little daughter, Si-Osire?

Father: ^We must part ways, Setna. Perhaps our paths will cross again.
^We are in need of you, Setna.
^Be calm. Where did you see her last?
^I cannot aid you. There are no mortal children where I go.
^My time is short; I must depart.
^Indeed, I have retrieved the Amulet of the Scarab. Now, join me and we shall face the abominations of Apophis together.
^Now that I feel the Amulet's power, I wish to keep it. I challenge you to a duel. (ATTACK)

c-5: ^I have retrieved the amulet so that High Priest Setna might safely travel with me, to the Netherworld, and retrieve their child. I am glad of the companionship, and the strength it brings.

c-6.#: I have it. And with it came despair. What bad omen are you, that my sun would be stolen so soon after we met? (ATTACK)

Father1: ^Si-Osire uttered a chant from the Scrolls of the Dead, and severed her soul from her mortal flesh.
^Why? The Scroll of the Dead is not a plaything.
^If her soul does not return to her body before my sun rises, she will be lost to the void. But what can I do?
PoorMan: ^We argued. It happened when two funeral caskets passed-by, one of cloth, and one encrusted with gems that glittered like stars!
^Si-Osire uttered a prayer. She wished for my corpse to share the fate of the poor scarab, when such a time comes.
^An insult! She then left to witness the fate of the poor and rich scarabs in the Netherworld. I must find her!
^Perhaps the poor scarab's fate was richer after his death?
^Surely you know that a mortal cannot enter the Netherworld and live? How do you expect to find her?

c-0: ^I must see for myself, and find my child!

Amulet: ^I need the Amulet of the Dead to protect my mortal soul as we pass through the Netherworld.
^If you retrieve it, I will fight the demons alongside you! We shall buoyed by the strength of our companionship.
^I shall grant you your wish and retrieve the amulet.
^Am I an errand-scarab or am I your God? You dare bargain with me? (ATTACK)

c-0: ^You have my eternal gratitude, King of Scarabs and Lord of the rising sun!

^Si-Osire, the child of High Priest Setna, has ventured into the Netherworld alone. I have agreed to retrieve the Amulet of the Dead, so that Setna might safely travel with me to the Netherworld and rescue the child.
c-1: ^Yes! And I call upon my loyal servants to attack!

b: ^What brings you here? Has your master Ra freed you from your nightly errand?
^Greetings, my friend Khepri, the lord of the rising sun!

Ammit: ^We must part ways. Perhaps our paths will cross again.
^We are in need of you, Ammit. Join me.
^Ammit, my old friend. Or is it Ammit the Betrayer?
^Enough banter. Perhaps we might travel together this night?
^I am my own master.I battle with the Netherworld, so the sun may yet rise. Enough of this disrespect (ATTACK).
^Have you heard of stirrings from the Netherworld, dear friend?

s1: ^What a sight you are! Is something the matter?

c-2: ^I have found the traitor at last. My former ally has colluded with the beasts of the Netherworld. But what if more of my scarabs have joined the army of the dead?
^Khepri, open your eyes! Lunu belongs to the Netherworld.

b: ^It would be my honor to be among your companions.
^Join you? When I might become Ammit, Devourer of Souls and have an army of mine own? Never.

c-5: ^I have heard that beasts are rising up to the surface. They wish to overthrough the surface Gods and claim Lunu as their own.
c-6: ^I have heard that many of our scarab siblings may not be what they seem.

b: ^Greetings! May I interest you in some wares?

s2: ^She strokes her necklace, a scarab carved of lapiz lazuli

Meri: ^I do not want your miserable fruit, merchant. Have you knives? Have you spells?
^I see the Amulet of the Scarab hangs upon your neck. How much for it?
^The Ancient Crone's potion of charisma. Here, take it.

s1: ^Not now, perhaps I shall return later.

c-0: ^Ah! I had maces! I had knifes of the most splended silver!
^Alas, my crate of weaponry was pilfered by dark spirits this morning.
^May Sekhmet bless me with more stock!

s0: ^Of course! Do not mind the wasps, they merely add a little spice.
s1: ^ Take more than a sample, my Lord!
s2: ^ You will want a crateful once you have tried this.

c-4: ^Come again soon, I always have new stock!
^Do not forget to visit my tent, Meri's Shop of Merriments, it lies to the east.

AmuletQuest: ^This amulet is priceless...you cannot buy it. Not with gold at least.
^If you will not exchange it for gold, then what will you take?
^You deny me? You refuse the Lord of the setting sun, the King of Scarabs?
Fetch: ^...I will give you my amulet in exchange for a favour, my king.
^If I may be so bold as to ask...?
^Find me a Potion of Charisma, one held by the Ancient Queen of Crones.
^Is that all? A simple task. Consider it completed
^You could have asked for much more, my dear. You shall have your Potion of Charisma
Reason: ^Praise Ra! Soon I shall coat my tongue in silver and charm the fortune back into my little tent!
AncientCrone: ^You there! Remove yourself from my land.

s: ^One moment of your time, Ancient Crone...

s0: ^Let me rest a moment longer, King of Scarabs.
s1: ^You rouse me too soon, my Lord
s2: ^We may travel together later, King Khepri

s: ^Rest now, I shall return this night.

s0: ^I have ensnared many of freshly dead this day.
s1: ^ We have many corpses joining us in the Netherworld, my Lord.
